content.content: Frontier Research LLC Delegate Platform  Key Info Name: Frontier Research LLC Delegate Address: 0x316090e23cc44e70245ba9846404413aca2df16f Forum: @Matt_NZ Discord: Matt_NZ#2697 Email: [email protected] Meet Your Delegate Video: Meet Your Delegate | Ep.18 ft. @Yano and @Matt_NZ - YouTube  Delegate Statement  About Me •	I am a lawyer and legal academic from New Zealand, specializing in law and technology. I am specifically interested in DeFi, decentralized governance, and the broader regulatory paradigm for emerging technologies. •	From private practice, I have experience advising large corporates and organizations about a range of strategy and legal issues relating to technology. I am a problem solver by trade and a moderate by temperament. •	I am a long-term small MKR holder, having watched the project evolve since 2019. I deeply care about Maker, and believe in its potential to sit at the heart of a thriving DeFi ecosystem. I want to dedicate my time, knowledge and skills to help bring that vision about.  My Values and Priorities  An emphasis on long-term strategy and growth. •	Maker is at a critical juncture. There is a real opportunity in this market to cement DAI’s place as the leading decentralized stablecoin, and Maker’s place as the standard-setting protocol in DeFi. Given the huge scale of that opportunity, I believe that Maker should keep the big picture in mind and double down on growth. •	Growth does not and should not mean the wanton squandering of resources during a bear market. Instead, it looks like Maker proactively developing internal capabilities and external integrations. It looks like generating revenue from idle assets by monetizing our balance sheet, continuing with the work of relationship-building with top-tier RWA partners, and taking early market share on L2s like StarkNet, Optimism and Arbitrum. •	One of my motivators for becoming a Recognized Delegate is to combat the myopia that tends to pervade the crypto world during a bear market. It always bears repeating that the TAM for Maker is ridiculously large. To capture that opportunity and maximise value for MKR holders, we must continue building, scaling, and hardening the protocol with an eye to the future.  Improving governance and organizational decision-making. •	While Maker is light years ahead of other DAOs, we have a long way to go to build a truly effective organization and governance system. As others have variously pointed out, we have several structural issues at Maker: a lack of cohesive strategy, too much complexity, broad apathy on the part of MKR holders, etc. •	I support shrinking the governance footprint, particularly with smaller MKR holders in mind. It is self-evidently impossible for most MKR holders to keep up with the forum, let alone make informed decisions on complex governance decisions. The spiral of complexity also makes it harder for delegates to effectively size and weigh decisions, and for other stakeholders to understand how Maker works. I welcome initiatives like this recent proposal from SES, for instance, to help combat these problems. •	Balancing meaningful decentralization with operational effectiveness is in many ways Maker’s primary challenge. These are difficult questions, particularly in a complicated protocol like Maker, and I do not think that one-dimensional or maximalist perspectives help resolve them. We have lessons to learn from the corporate governance literature, and things to figure out on our own about how to craft the right incentives for effective decentralized governance.  Providing an independent voice and fact-based scrutiny. •	I think it is pivotal to Maker’s governance that delegates can apply a critical and fact-based lens to each vote, without pressure to vote in a particular way. For that reason, I want to make it clear that Frontier Research will be participating in governance as a fully independent delegate. •	In terms of the Endgame, I support the general goal of ossifying core functions and making them more resilient. However, the Endgame Plan is a complex proposal with many moving parts that each merit individual scrutiny. I have a track record of asking some unpopular but important questions on this and other topics (see here, here and here as examples). MKR holders deserve independent representation, particularly on protocol-defining shifts such as the Endgame. •	Finally, I see part of the value I can bring as an independent delegate is that of a bridge-builder and pragmatist. I am concerned about the increasing politicization and polarization of Maker and do not want to see the community fractured into ‘sides’ or ‘teams’. Much more unites us at Maker than divides us, and crafting a long-term vision should help to underline that reality.  Conflicts of Interest •	ETH and MKR are my only significant (>5% total value) crypto holdings. •	I have no investments or interests that should impact my role as a delegate. •	I have been contributing research and analysis to GovAlpha, largely applying political science theory/analysis to Maker’s governance systems. This work was strictly ad-hoc, limited in scope and I was not a member of the GovAlpha CU. I have ceased my contributions to GovAlpha and will not seek paid work at Maker beyond my role as a Recognized Delegate. •	I have read, agree with, and agree to abide by the Delegate Code of Conduct.  Waiver of Liability By delegating to Frontier Research you acknowledge and agree that I will not be held liable for any damages or losses caused by my participation in the Maker Protocol or because of any votes cast or actions taken while acting as a delegate. I do not have a fiduciary or any other obligation to you as a result of your delegation of MKR to the Frontier Research delegation contract. By delegating your MKR you accept the outcome of votes made on your behalf by Frontier Research, and specifically agree that at all times you have complete control over the delegated assets by adding or removing your MKR from the delegation contract.

content.content: ChrisBlec:  But why wasn’t approval for the $50k spend just included in the original MIP?     The MIP6 application was just a request to onboard collateral from the applicant. Domain work are all the implementation reviews Maker does for its own behalf. All of the spend we are contemplating to conduct independent legal due diligence would have otherwise come out of the RWF budget. To work around the current paralysis, we agreed at earlier collateral meetings that SF would shepherd through MIP65 and the Backed Finance MIP6 work. Any funding dedicated to this domain work will correspondingly not be spent by RWF, and will only be spent for this legal work.   This has more to do with internal processes than with anything else: linked reply for more details.  Either we updated the original ask in our SPF request or we proceeded step by step as we are doing now depending on final cost estimates, rather than pad the ask and draw more than we really need (even if we return it after) We took a more cautious approach with the funding request at the expense of potentially one more SPF request.    The estimates are as follows:    MIP55c3-SP6: Legal Domain Work on Greenlit Collateral (bIBTA) Special Purpose Fund    12-16k CHF from top-tier Swiss legal firms to cover compliance with Swiss law max. 20k USD from North Lakes Legal to coordinate project 40-60k USD from a white-shoe US firm to cover US implications    We had been working off ~15k Swiss, ~15k US and the rest NLL. Top tier US firms came in more expensive than we expected. The high-end estimate could come in as high as $96k. The low-end in the $70k range, sizing a second SPF in the $20-46k range should it come to that. It could still well prove to be unnecessary as all legal work in this area is highly innovative and difficult to evaluate time estimates.     ChrisBlec:  No, the DAO shouldn’t just be allowing CUs to grab whatever money they need. It needs to be approved.   Fully agreed. Any request for SPF, including this one, has to go through governance. Understanding that the above estimates are a fair assessment of the high-end extent of this request. The net of it is:  If you do not want to engage with the RWA domain but you do not want to obstruct work being done, you should abstain on all SPF requests including this one If you do not wish domain work to be funded independently by SF you should reject all SPF requests including this one If you wish domain work to be done you should approve this SPF request but also be prepared to approve a potential second one to close the gap

content.content: Votes Cast September 16 2022 Polls Ratification Poll for Amend Measurement Period For Delegate Participation Metrics (MIP4c2-SP24) - September 12, 2022 (thread) Voted: Yes  This poll affects Frontier Research as a delegate, in the sense that if our participation metrics were to fall in the future (they are currently 100%) this would make the impact of any missed votes or communications less permanent. With that potential conflict flagged, this amendment (as well as the Delegates MIP Set) is worth supporting as an improvement to a governance system that everyone recognizes as a work in progress. The example of Hasu earlier this year demonstrates how just a few missed votes can scar a delegate’s metrics (and, accordingly, their compensation) into the future. While there is a balance to be struck, as the protocol needs delegates to be active and engaged, this amendment improves that balance on the margins. Ratification Poll for the MakerDAO Delegates MIP Set - September 12, 2022 (thread) Voted: Yes  Similarly, this MIP set represents a series of substantive improvements to the delegate system, put together by GovAlpha. As above, this vote affects Frontier Research into the future, to a greater extent than the participation metrics as it changes the compensation mechanic and adds MKR vesting. For that reason, I was close to abstaining on this poll. However, GovAlpha have been meticulous and comprehensive in their development of this MIP set and I endorse that independent process. Ratification Poll for Modify GovAlpha Core Unit MKR Budget (MIP40c3-SP80) - September 12, 2022 (thread) Voted: Abstain  I am abstaining from this poll, having completed some research and analysis work as a contributor to GovAlpha earlier this year (this is flagged in more detail in my delegate platform above).

content.content: Endgame Position Statement Frontier Research might be a newish delegate platform, but I have been following the development of the Endgame Plan right from ideation by Rune to this current vote for the Prelaunch MIP Set. While our views about the Endgame Plan have shifted quite a bit (particularly as the plan itself has morphed, sometimes - encouragingly - in line with community feedback), there are still some outstanding concerns. The main points factoring into the Frontier position at this stage are:   Organizational complexity and complication. Despite some simplification, the Endgame Plan is hugely complex and the learning curve is beyond what 99% of DeFi community members could surmount. This would not necessarily be a decisive blow except that the Endgame is relying on the development of bespoke communities for MetaDAOs; it is not clear why those will develop beyond the current Maker community, outside some less-than-compelling token emissions.   The tokenomics of MetaDAOs still seem unclear and unconvincing given it is unclear how MetaDAOs will each develop sustainable revenue or business models, and it looks like they will need to be financed by Maker Core for a considerable period of time. I spelled out some of these concerns here, which in fairness Rune responded to at length. I understand his case in favour but it seems reasonably speculative at this stage.   On the other hand, seeing the proposed launch of numerous clusters has been heartening. There are strong, technical teams being put together to make the Endgame a success and this is what the best-case scenario for a post-Endgame Maker looks like: decentralized, autonomous units all building under the aegis of Maker.   Overall, while it is abundantly clear that Maker could use the shake-up and reinvigoration that Rune’s plan will undoubtedly deliver, too many critical mechanics remain unspecified and unclear. In the hope that Maker will continue to develop the Endgame Plan atomically and incrementally, we vote to abstain at this stage rather than cast a vote for or against. If the Endgame is passed by governance, we will of course abide and look to work to make the transition as successful as possible; including by continuing to point out opportunities and potential areas of weakness.  Votes Cast October 22 2022 Accordingly: Polls Ratification Poll for Endgame Prelaunch MIP Set - October 10, 2022 (thread) Voted: Abstain  Ratification Poll for Offboarding the Strategic Happiness Core Unit - SH-001 (MIP39c3-SP3) - October 10, 2022 (thread) Voted: Yes  Happy for offboarding to occur on Rune’s terms as opposed to the previous proposal. Ratification Poll for Offboarding the Events Core Unit - EVENTS-001 (MIP39c3-SP4) - October 10, 2022 (thread) Voted: Yes  The Events team have done some great work and have not been treated particularly fairly by Maker governance. However, signalling agreement with the terms of the Golden Parachute set out in this proposal. content.content: Votes Cast November 22 2022 (Strap in for a big day at the polls!) Polls Ratification Poll for Immunefi Security Core Unit (IS-001) Facilitator Onboarding (MIP41c4-SP38) - November 14, 2022 (thread) Voted: Yes  Psychonaut/Pritkin, for all intents and purposes, is the facilitator for IS-001 - at least, he is performing that role in the absence of the titular facilitator. There are clearly some concerns about this particular facilitator onboarding but we should also consider the bad precedent of having a facilitator who seems more or less AWOL in that role. On balance, we support this change. Budget Ratification Poll for Modify Development and UX Core Unit (DUX-001) Budget (MIP40c3-SP82) - November 14, 2022 (thread) Voted: 1st choice: Approve reduced budget - NewBase  2nd choice: Approve existing budget only 3rd choice: Approve reduced budget - NewBear DUX have done some outstanding work in the last year and (as previously noted in earlier posts) their work on UX for delegation and voting is particularly top-notch. This work will only become more important in the next year or so with the changes that the Endgame Plan will bring. That said, prudence given budget cuts across CUs is appreciated and so we have accordingly preferenced the ‘NewBase’ option (followed by ‘existing budget’ and ‘NewBear’). Ratification Poll for CoinShares Active Treasury Management (MIP86) - November 14, 2022 (thread) Voted: No  It is concerning that CoinShares has significant ($30m) exposure to FTX, amounting to 11% of net assets per CoinShares’ post here. and there appears to be some uncertainty about other market participants at this (calamitous) period for the industry. In light of that uncertainty, our preference is for caution. This is a shame as CoinShare’s proposal was comprehensive and the diversification of yield would have been healthy for Maker - this poll should by no means be the end of CoinShares’ possible collaboration with Maker. Ratification Poll for OUSD Decentralized Rewards (MIP87) - November 14, 2022 (thread) Voted: No  We take Risk CU’s recommendations and analysis seriously, and their laundry list of issues with this MIP and the OUSD proposal is more than enough to reject this ratification poll. Ratification Poll for Modify Immunefi Security Core Unit (IS-001) Mandate (MIP39c2-SP38) - November 14, 2022 (thread) Voted: Yes  These changes to IS-001’s mandate make sense and seem to reflect what is generally happening with that CU (as an aside, though, this is the kind of change that in an ideal world would not have its own poll - we should be trying to reduce governance overhead where possible). Budget Ratification Poll for Modify Immunefi Security (IS-001) Budget (MIP40c3-SP83) - November 14, 2022 (thread) Voted: 1st choice: Approve reduced budget - BearMarket   2nd choice: Reject budget The aggressive cuts proposed by the CU to their own budget seem appropriate in the circumstances, and it is worth asking the question whether a bug bounty program should be administered by a separate CU as opposed to a broader CU or an external provider. For now, however, happy to vote to approve the significantly reduced budget. Budget Ratification Poll for Modify Governance Communications Core Unit DAI Budget, COM-001 (MIP40c3-SP84) - November 14, 2022 (thread) Voted: Approve Budget  Again, it is important to recognize that the CU has looked to cut its own budget at first instance in the context of broader cuts across the CUs. I actually don’t know if Recognized Delegates are particularly well-placed to assess whether GovComms is doing a good job at facilitating internal collaboration/aligning stakeholders etc among the CUs, but from the outside it appears that this is what is happening. It’s also worth noting that the total budget for this CU is relatively small - notably, a significantly smaller outlay than the following CU. Budget Ratification Poll for Modify Sidestream Auction Services Core Unit DAI Budget, SAS-001 (MIP40c3-SP85) - November 14, 2022 (thread) Voted: 1st choice: Reject budget   It is not at all clear that the DAO is getting value for its annual spend of $1m for this CU (or $950k for the proposed bear budget). That is a lot of money to spend for an interface for Maker’s auction systems and it is hard to justify that level of spend for the output. While it is true that Maker’s auctions have worked very well, it is difficult to quantify the contribution of SAS-001. Budget Ratification Poll for Modify TechOps Core Unit DAI Budget, TECH-001 (MIP40c3-SP86) - November 14, 2022 (thread) Voted: Approve Budget  TechOps support Maker’s underlying infrastructure, including critical infrastructure, and that work needs to be valued highly by governance. The spend here ($2.4m annual) is significant but so too is the breadth of the work this CU needs to support - including 24/7/365 support with contributors based around the globe. TECH support the front-line work of other CUs and also seem to have reduced infrastructure costs through their efforts. Their proposed budget should be approved. Ratification Poll for Modify Emulated Surplus Buffer Upper Limit (MIP84c10-SP1) - November 14, 2022 (thread) Voted: Abstain  This vote seems to mostly be about winding back the very recent vote among the Endgame MIP set about approving the POVE. While I am sympathetic to the concern here and some of POVE’s risk, it is not appropriate to try to essentially handicap a key vote that governance passed just last month. Accordingly, we cannot support this poll. Ratification Poll for Monetalis - Redwood Friesian (MIP88) - November 14, 2022 (thread) Voted: Yes  It is true that the protocol’s concentrated exposure to Monetalis is a concern (and we have previously abstained from the Appaloosa ratification poll for this reason). These counterparty risks remain a concern, obviously with regard to both the Friesian and Andalusian votes. However, calls/a strong presentation by the proposed Viridian Cluster have prompted a bit of a rethink: these vaults represent reasonable yield for Maker, but more importantly, the cluster model represents the path forward for RWA under the Endgame Plan. With governance having now voted in favour of this direction, it’s important to provide the nascent Viridian Cluster with a chance to establish their operating model. Ratification Poll for Monetalis - Arrow Andalusian (MIP89) - November 14, 2022 (thread) Voted: Yes  Similar explanation to the previous vote, with an addendum on this specific proposal that the Viridian Cluster’s emphasis in their presentation and writing about climate-aligned collateral is really promising. As I have written about previously, Maker has a huge opportunity here and I endorse efforts to advance the protocol in a greener direction. Budget Ratification Poll for Modify the Sustainable Ecosystem Scaling Core Unit DAI Budget, SES-001 (MIP40c3-SP87) - November 14, 2022 (thread) Voted: 1st choice: Approve standard option budget  SES play an important role within Maker and their proposed budget should be approved, but it is noteworthy that the budget here is not small ($2.7m). The budget cutting is appreciated and so we prefer the smaller budget (ie, the standard option budget). Add GNO (GnosisDAO) as a new Vault Type - November 21, 2022 (thread) Voted: Yes  There are some liquidity questions around GNO and it may not be likely to drive much revenue for Maker, but on balance it is still worth voting to add as a new vault type. Maker’s relationship with Gnosis goes beyond GNO and we have a strategic interest of course in supporting DAI as a flagship stablecoin, with which Gnosis is also aligned. The parameters here (collateral liquidation ratio of 350%) are conservative too which reduces risk. Hoping to see others get in behind this vote as well. Add Multiple BlockTower Credit Vault Types (RWA010, RWA011, RWA012, RWA013) - November 21, 2022 (thread) Voted: Yes  Have previously supported Maker working with BlockTower as a high-calibre partner and continue to do so, particularly to drive protocol revenue. There are also some cool and innovative things going on in this proposal with Centrifuge that we will watch with interest. As a final point, some of my comments about the Viridian Cluster above are also relevant here to the long-term direction for the Spring Cluster. Offboarding Parameters for renBTC-A - November 21, 2022 (thread) Voted: Yes  Yes, for sure. Ren Protocol is being sunset and needs to be offboarded promptly. Proceed with Pre-Implementation Work for the Deal Outlined in MIP90 (BlockTower Liquid AAA Structured Credit and Money Market Fund) - November 21, 2022 (thread) Voted: Yes (Proceed)  Yes, this pre-implementation work needs to be done, we are glad to see SF take the lead, and approve their proposed plan in this instance.

content.content: Votes Cast November 29 2022 Polls DAI Savings Rate Adjustment - November 28, 2022 (thread) Voted: 1st choice: Increase the DSR to 1%   2nd choice: Increase the DSR to 0.75% 3rd choice: Increase the DSR to 0.5% 4th choice: Increase the DSR to 0.25% Strongly support increasing the DSR to 1%, and encourage other delegates and community members to do the same. As I spelled out in this thread, Maker has a pretty unique growth opportunity given the conflux of FTX/CEX disaster and our own increasing revenue. The DSR represents a way to return value to existing DAI holders and change the value proposition of DAI for prospective new users and any capital currently sitting on the sidelines. That has clear positive ramifications from the broader perspective of Maker’s competitive positioning, including by encouraging more integrations. For anyone on the fence, it’s worth reading this thread and I would highlight @monet-supply’s point here: (emphasis added)    Parameter Changes Proposal - PPG-OMC-001 - 24 November 2022   For example, if Maker set DSR to 1% and Aave v2 and Compound integrated it for idle liquidity, this would increase supply rates by ~0.42% for Aave (from 1.3% to 1.72%) and ~0.48% for Compound (from 1.92% to 2.4% including COMP rewards). While still below tbill rates this would make DAI a more attractive asset to integrate for defi protocols   @hexonaut’s argument here also resonates: (emphasis added)    Parameter Changes Proposal - PPG-OMC-001 - 24 November 2022   In general I find Maker can sometimes move too slow on these sort of opportunities due to the very human need to move slowly into uncharted territory. I completely understand and sometimes feel similarly, but would like to stress that existential exposure to a single counter-party is existential no matter if we are at 1b or 5b exposure. We might as well dial it up and get the benefit if we must have it.   Let’s put a stake in the ground for DAI and for decentralized growth, and get the DSR going. PPG - Open Market Committee Proposal - November 28, 2022 (thread) Voted: Yes  Generally support the MOMC’s proposed parameter shifts and this vote is no exception. Each change makes sense and the justifications are characteristically sound. Undertake Necessary Risk and Legal Assessments to Increase the NS-DROP Debt Ceiling to 50 Million DAI - November 28, 2022 (thread) Voted: Yes  Good to evaluate this opportunity and of course the risk and legal assessments are necessary (as the title suggests). Happy to see the success of the NS-DROP vault and the voluntary suggested increase in stability fee (to 4.5%).

content.content: Votes Cast January 18 2023 Polls Adjust the GUSD PSM Debt Ceiling - January 16, 2023 (thread) Voted: 1st choice: No change (500 million DAI).   The debate and rigour around this issue has been good to see (it is worth acknowledging the Gemini team and Tyler himself for engaging with the community both in the forum and in Discord). It seems plausible, as Tyler claims, that the Earn issues do not impact any other Gemini products like GUSD. Considering the broader constellation of points raised both by Gemini and its critics, we find it reasonably assuring that the GUSD reserves are segregated from Gemini (a company subject to New York Banking Law). The critical question is whether GUSD would still be redeemable in the event of a Gemini meltdown, and that those reserves are out of reach from the company (or its creditors). The endless volume of centralized meltdowns in crypto means we need to take this contingency possibility seriously, but neither should we overreact and attempt to end an integration that has been productive for Maker given most factors suggest the GUSD reserves are sound. At this point in time, on balance, we support staying the course with GUSD. Decrease GUSD PSM Fee Out (tout) - January 16, 2023 (thread) Voted: No  In addition to the above comment, it is not necessarily clear that decreasing the GUSD PSM fee would  actually provide Maker with meaningful protection or optionality as some voters seem to be suggesting. In practice, the 500m is not going anywhere in a hurry. If the community decides that GUSD presents a catastrophic or existential risk to Maker, that is the prerogative of MKR voters: this proposal, however, does not move the needle meaningfully in either direction.

content.content: Votes Cast January 19 2023 Polls Ratification Poll for Special Purpose Fund for developing Proof-of-Performance for Viridian Cluster (MIP55c3-SP13) - January 9, 2023 (thread) Voted: No  Wanted to hear from the Viridian Cluster in today’s G&R call before coming down on this poll. I agree with Rajiv that there is some confusion as to overlap and competition with SF CU. It is not immediately clear, as other delegates (particularly GFX) have pointed out, why the SPF should fund the cluster’s monitoring of RWA  given the scope of SF CU as it stands currently (and, generally, the need for Maker to have its own monitoring). As we have outlined in vote commentary last year, some of the Viridian Cluster’s plans for RWA going forward are genuinely exciting. But in lieu of clarity around the cluster’s role in the broader context of Maker Core, it seems imprudent to support this particular SPF. Ratification Poll for Core Unit Offboarding (COM-001) (MIP39c3-SP7) - January 9, 2023 (thread) Voted: 1st choice: Approve Offboarding, 60,700 DAI Golden Parachute and 100% Multiplier for retroactive MKR - additional 107,317.50 DAI (CU-preferred)   2nd choice: Approve Offboarding, 60,700 DAI Golden Parachute and 80% Multiplier for retroactive MKR - additional 85,854 DAI In support of a reasonable and balanced offboarding process for COM-001, including the 100% multiplier for retroactive MKR. It is in governance’s interest as we have set out before to provide support that is fair and decent for staff/workers/CUs that are winding up. Ratification Poll for Requesting Protocol DAI Transfer to fund TechOps CU for February 2023 (MIP14c2-SP1) - January 9, 2023 (thread) Voted: Yes  A reasonable bridging proposal to fund TechOps CU. Ratification Poll for Protocol DAI Transfer to Fund IS-001 from Dec 2022 to May 2023 (MIP14c2-SP2) - January 9, 2023 (thread) Voted: Yes  Again, a reasonable bridging proposal. Ratification Poll for Commercial Risk and Legal Domain Work to Support SF-001 Expanded Mandate Related to RWAs (MIP55c3-SP12) - January 9, 2023 (thread) Voted: Yes  Given the massive role that SF now plays across the protocol, it is critical that they have budget for completing commercial risk and legal domain work. This is crucial spend. Ratification Poll for Declaration of Intent to Develop a Comprehensive On-chain Monitoring Solution for RWA Vaults (MIP13c3-SP13) - January 9, 2023 (thread) Voted: Yes  This is a RWA monitoring proposal we can get behind: developing a robust and comprehensive risk monitoring solution for Maker Core is an important medium-term goal and we look forward to the solutions that might be offered as a result of this push. Ratification Poll for Defense Fund (MIP55c3-SP14) - January 9, 2023 (thread) Voted: Abstain  This is a complex issue. There is no denying that there is a clear need for Maker to think through how it should respond/support responses to legal and regulatory actions, including reimbursement of expenses for individuals. However, as a Recognized Delegate, we do not feel comfortable voting in support of a proposal with the explicit objective of reimbursing legal expenses for key stakeholders (delegates being the first group cited in the proposal): that veers uncomfortably close to a conflict of interests, whether perceived or actual. This is not a vote against the notion of a dedicated fund or legal resource per se, and the work going into the proposal is appreciated. Nevertheless, for the reasons above, we abstain. Ratification Poll for MIP63 Maker Keeper Network Amendment (MIP4c2-SP31) - January 9, 2023 (thread) Voted: Yes  These are logical and commonsense improvements to MIP63.

content.content: Votes Cast January 22 2023 Polls Ratification Poll for Amend MIP61 to tighten up Recognized Delegate Participation Metrics (MIP4c2-SP29) - January 9, 2023 (thread) Voted: 1st choice: Approve only the Higher Participation Requirements and Weighting for Executive Votes    Have made our views on abstention rules clear, including in the thread, so won’t belabour the point here. Again, while the motivation for this amendment is understandable, on balance it creates a worse set of incentives for recognized delegates and Maker governance. There is no evidence that mass abstentions are actually a problem for our governance systems at this point in time (most delegates, like our platform, abstain rarely). Happy, on the other hand, to see the weighting for executive votes go up along with more stringent participation requirements: given the pivotal operational and pseudo-constitutional role of executives in the system, there is no excuse really for delegates not to be all over those particular votes. Ratification Poll for Amend MIP51 to Remove MIP51c4 (Calendar Exceptions) (MIP4c2-SP28) - January 9, 2023 (thread) Voted: No  This was a tricky vote. The idea that Maker should retain flexibility in the month of December is reasonable, though it’s also true that governance could push urgent votes through if needed (arguably making the point moot). Overall, in recognition of the risks of burnout it seems reasonable to continue to earmark December as a break in the monthly governance cycle. As Derek mentions in the vote thread, the break is also designed to give developers a rest over the end of December. It seems worthwhile to continue to earmark that break in the cycle structure. Ratification Poll for MIP14 Repeal (MIP4c4-SP2) - January 9, 2023 (thread) Voted: No  While it is true that MIP14 has not exactly been a high-use MIP since inception, we agree with GovAlpha that there is utility in MIP14 filling in a gap for certain funding requests that don’t fit other structures. In fact, as another vote this cycle (“MIP4c2-SP32: Remove MIP14c4: Protocol DAI Transfer Ceiling”) highlights, the Endgame might usher in a series of increasingly substantial funding requests through MIP14 - this is not the time to repeal it. Ratification Poll for Obsolete MIP Removal (MIP23, MIP28) (MIP4c4-SP3) - January 9, 2023 (thread) Voted: Yes  This is a commonsense pruning process for obsolete MIPs. Ratification Poll for Remove MIP14c4 (Protocol DAI Transfer Ceiling) (MIP4c2-SP32) - January 9, 2023 (thread) Voted: Yes  As above, it’s clear that MIP14 is coming into more use and that a 250k ceiling could prove to be an annoying handicap on funding/budgeting processes. Removing that ceiling makes sense in that context. Ratification Poll for Onboard-Amend Keeper Network - Chainlink Automation (MIP63c4-SP5) - January 9, 2023 (thread) Voted: Yes  Really happy to see Chainlink Automation onboarded to the keeper pool, which should help bolster the  performance of essential protocol services as well as further improve Maker’s protocol decentralization. Decentralization in this context offers particularly valuable benefits like extra redundancy protection in the event another keeper network goes down. Ratification Poll for Onboard PSM USDC to Yearn to earn Yield (MIP92) - January 9, 2023 (thread) Voted: Yes  Supporting this vote in line with our platform’s emphasis on growth and yield as important priorities. While there is merit in some of the arguments raised against this proposal (the yield (2%) is not high; we could just implement certain strategies ourselves, etc), this particular proposal offers a way to test out a DeFi-native mechanism of earning yield beyond our significant RWA streams. It also helps that Yearn is offering to share fees with Maker. Overall, while yield farming will never be the path for Maker to generate massive growth, we support Yearn’s proposal for the reason Rema notes in that thread (emphasis added):    MIP92: Onboard PSM USDC to Yearn to earn Yield   While the current on-chain yield environment is suboptimal especially when compared to traditional financial benchmarks, we believe that such a module is valuable enough to justify allocating resources towards it, as risk/reward profile will most likely improve in the future

content.content: Votes Cast January 24 2023 Polls Adjust the Debt Floor (dust) - January 23, 2023  (thread) Voted: 1st choice: Option 1 - Broad Reduction  2nd choice: Option 2 - Limited Reduction This vote could be taken as an interesting prologue to a broader debate about who the community thinks Maker vaults should be for. Is it still important to maintain access to vaults for smaller users, which a broad reduction of dust helps achieve, or is it better to lean into the wholesale model and assume that users will end up on L2s in any case? In general, our platform sees the latter as the likelier path of travel. However, with respect to this particular vote, there does not appear to be much harm in adjusting the debt floor to offer more of a carrot to small users. We can always review and readjust these settings if there is a significant swing in the gas market that makes it uneconomic to liquidate small users (while that isn’t the best user experience, it beats pricing those users out of vaults altogether). Offboarding Parameters for USDC-A, USDP-A, and GUSD-A - January 23, 2023 (thread) Voted: Yes  Given that we have cleared out all positions on these vault types below the liquidation ratio, there is no real reason to keep them on the books. A good housekeeping proposal to offboard these vaults.

content.content: Votes Cast January 31 2023 Polls Short Ratification Poll for Requesting Protocol DAI Transfer to Fund Endgame Information Portal (MIP14c2-SP3) - January 30, 2023 (thread) Voted: Yes  Supporting this poll with a couple of nuances and observations. As set out in a prior post,  organizational complexity and complication is a serious obstacle that the Endgame will need to surmount over the next year or two: while some aspects have been simplified since, many have not, and the plan remains in a state of flux and development. This really matters in a context where SubDAOs/MetaDAOs will need to build communities outside the tiny Maker intelligentsia in order to thrive. On that basis, starting the process of developing a bespoke knowledge portal makes sense (it will be hard to drum up mass enthusiasm for the Endgame by directing people to the Maker Operational Manual - we need simple explainers more than anything else). I’m not sure if $10k will be enough to attract a sufficiently high-quality proposal, but it’s worth a shot, and testing out new decentralized voting systems (ie, JokeDAO) is also worthwhile for relatively low cost.

content.content: Votes Cast Feb 14 2023 Polls Ratification Poll - Declaration of Intent - Implement a Feature to Refund People who Lost Money Sending Dai to the Dai Contract Address (MIP13c3-SP14) - February 13, 2023 (thread) Voted: No  This is a pain point for at least some number of DAI users and of course in a perfect world there would be some form of mechanism to provide for those people genuinely out of pocket. However, it is difficult to justify the institutional resources on this initiative at this point in time. There is a confluence of tricky governance, engineering and organisational shifts happening at the moment and it is important that Maker focuses on top priorities (ie, at least for this delegate platform: growing Maker, and successfully executing the Endgame Plan). Ratification Poll for Restart a daily $100 Micro-Burn of MKR in Show of Good Faith to MKR Holders (MIP74c1-SP1) - February 13, 2023 (thread) Voted: No  There are similar factors here to consider in terms of institutional resources and what we think Maker should focus on. This is explicitly a symbolic gesture, and while symbolic gestures can sometimes be worthwhile, anything tokenistic should be put on pause for the next few months or likely more as the Endgame comes into focus. Additionally, the Endgame will change the tokenomics for MKR to a pretty drastic degree, possibly rendering this initiative obsolete in any case.

content.content: Votes Cast Feb 21 2023 Polls Ratification Poll for Amend MIP62 to Allow for Changing Communication Responsibilities (MIP4c2-SP33) - February 13, 2023 (thread) Voted: Yes  With GovComms offboarded, this logical proposal instead gives GovAlpha responsibility for communication of future offboardings (and simplifies some of the procedural requirements). Ratification Poll for Amend Interim Facilitator Appointment Process (MIP4c2-SP30) - February 13, 2023 (thread) Voted: Yes  The existing interim facilitator appointment process has shown to be a bit slow and cumbersome. This is another set of logical procedural changes, in this case to better maintain business continuity with a more tightly conceived interim facilitator role where the need arises. Ratification Poll for $100M of Cogent Bank Loan Participations (MIP95) - February 13, 2023 (thread) Voted: Yes  It is difficult to overstate the importance of RWA revenue to Maker in its present state and likely into the future. While there are bottleneck issues given capacity demands on the Maker workforce, this proposal with Cogent Bank ticks a lot of boxes. Like with Huntington Valley Bank, Cogent represents a way for Maker to finance real economic activity and double down on its value proposition for community banks. Cogent is FDIC regulated and relatively well established. Scaling the protocol’s revenue must continue to be a priority for governance, and Cogent (based in Florida) also helps us diversify our integrations. While we respect the views of other delegates that the Endgame constitutional processes should take priority at this point in time, we should still continue to look to grow Maker’s footprint and revenue. Audit and Review Work for Phoenix Labs - February 20, 2023 (thread) Voted: Yes  In a similar vein, we think it would be a mistake for the lack of fully defined Endgame frameworks to get in the way of genuine product innovation and protocol expansion. While constitutional discussions are important and ongoing, nobody should forget that the Endgame will only be successful if SubDAOs help expand Maker’s utility and drive innovative new products. To that end, dedicating resources towards a proven team like Phoenix Labs should be seen as a helpful building block for a successful Endgame transition. Engineering Resource for Phoenix Labs - February 20, 2023 (thread) Voted: Yes  As above, this is a helpful signal for governance to send in favour of what a successful Endgame transition requires in practice. The effort from Derek to clarify governance’s intent is more than reasonable in the confusing circumstances of that transition, and hopefully governance can respond with a clear signal in support. With the Endgame in an embryonic state, this is a particularly important time for the protocol to double down on growth through innovation. Remember that the team have committed that Maker will own and benefit from every product that Phoenix Labs creates: this is a no-brainer bet for governance, and one worth supporting in full.
